image.altText: People running across a dirt road in a remote community in front of a house

props.synopsis: Long-standing tensions between feuding family groups reached crisis point in the Northern Territory's remote west in early 2022. The response of two police officers has now been recognised.

title.children: 'A very intense situation': NT police officers win bravery award for Wadeye riot response

image.altText: A close up photo of a phone with dating apps like Tinder, Grindr and Bumble on the screen.

props.synopsis: Popular online dating platforms are being threatened with greater government regulation unless they lift their standards and improve safety for users.

title.children: Dating apps threatened with regulation unless they improve safety

image.altText: Chris Bowen in a navy suit and tie in  front of the australian flag at a press conference

props.synopsis: The federal government releases figures to try to shut down growing calls from the opposition to consider nuclear as part of Australia's future energy mix, with Energy Minister Chris Bowen saying there would be a "massive cost to pay".

title.children: Energy Minister says replacing coal-fired power stations with nuclear would cost $387 billion

image.altText: A man in a suit is interviewed for television.

props.synopsis: One of the taxpayers helped by ATO whistleblower Richard Boyle has spoken out for the first time, describing the prosecution of the person who gave him a lifeline as "insanity". Mr Boyle's wife has also spoken to 7.30 about the toll the six-year-long ordeal has taken on the couple.

title.children: Richard Boyle faces the prospect of four decades in jail. His wife says all he did was tell the truth

image.altText: Three Wallabies players stand on the ground after the 2023 Rugby World Cup loss to Fiji.

props.synopsis: Never before have the Wallabies exited the Rugby World Cup at the pool stage, but the 22-15 result against Fiji has left Eddie Jones's squad in danger of missing the quarterfinals, writes Luke Pentony.

title.children: Wallabies' 'smash and grab campaign' on the brink of unravelling — and they only have themselves to blame

image.altText: Norman standing in his home with cleaning products behind him.

props.synopsis: Elder Norman Frank Jupurrurla has been forced to leave his public housing twice in six months following bed bug outbreaks at his home in Village Camp, a community living area on the outskirts of Tennant Creek.

title.children: 'It's like hell': Bed bug outbreaks have caused Norm to lose his home twice in six months

image.altText: One man wears a cap and blue check shirt and jeans smiling, another in denim jacket and shoulder length hair, smiling

props.synopsis: One of Australia's biggest rock bands, Silverchair ended with a whimper, not a bang. And so too did their friendships … almost.

title.children: 'We should have gone out in a blaze of glory': What really tore Silverchair apart

image.altText: Students in a classroom with male teacher in background.

props.synopsis: Poor mental health and excessive screen time are the biggest problems facing young people, according to a new survey of more than 2,000 Australian teachers. New resources will be made available for teachers in a hope to create more conversations on mental wellbeing.

title.children: 'Nervous rants' and crying at school: Teachers say poor mental health is the biggest issue facing Australia's youth

image.altText: Multiple neighbours characters look surprised

props.synopsis: Neighbours received an all-star send off in 2022 but now the beloved Australian soap is heading back to TV.

title.children: Neighbours returns to Australian screens tonight. Here's how to watch it and why it's back

image.altText: Business people walk past a shiny black sign that reads "Reserve Bank of Australia".

props.synopsis: The Australian share market is trading lower as investors wait for foreign central banks' next interest rates meetings, while Michele Bullock begins her first seven-year term as RBA governor. Follow live.

title.children: New dawn at the RBA as Michele Bullock begins as governor, ASX lower ahead of overseas interest rates meetings

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Even though the Senate Committee on Commonwealth Bilateral Air Service Agreements was established to examine why Qatar Airways was rejected for additional flights (among other things) the airline won't appear at the committee's first public hearing tomorrow. Committee member and Labor Senator Tony Sheldon says it was "very disappointing" that Qatar Airways refused to accept the invitation. "If the Liberals and Nationals want to give Qatar’s state-owned airline open entry, the Senate needs to scrutinise its practices ," the Senator said. "[Qatar Airways CEO Akbar] Al Baker should front up to this Inquiry rather than provide commentary about Australia from the other side of the world. "Mr Al Baker is no more above the law or parliamentary scrutiny than [Qantas Chairman Richard] Goyder or [Qantas CEO Vanessa] Hudson, and I expect to see all of them at this inquiry. "Qatar Airways and the Qatar Civil Aviation Authority need to be hauled before this Committee in the coming days." Tomorrow's first public hearing will be held in Sydney, before moving to Perth for a second hearing on Friday. Hearings will resume the following week in Brisbane before heading to Canberra. A report is expected to be handed down in October.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Qatar Airways won't appear at tomorrow's Senate hearing into air service agreements

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Philip Lowe era at the Reserve Bank ended last Friday after 43 years. In his final public appearance, Mr Lowe said he was proud of his record, but admitted the latter part of his tenure became defined by his forward guidance on rates. Michele Bullock takes over the helm today, but it's likely her start will be without fanfare — her first meeting as governor next month is not expected to see a change to the cash rate. Former RBA economist and now lecturer at Monash University, Zac Gross, says it's too soon to write Philip Lowe's final report card. You can watch his full chat with Close of Business host Rachel Pupazzoni below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 📺 ICYMI: What next for the RBA after Philip Lowe's departure?

document.title: What's next for the Reserve Bank after Philip Lowe's departure?

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: You're going to be hearing a lot about the interest rate decisions made by other central banks this week — and while I don't have a crystal ball about what the outcome will be, I can tell you what analysts are predicting to happen. The US Federal Reserve, Bank of England and Bank of Japan are all meeting this week to decide what to do with its cash rate policy, with the Fed up first. It also comes after the European Central Bank (ECB) lifted rates to 4% at its latest meeting — the highest level since the Euro launched — with its president Christine Lagarde hinting rates may have now peaked. Here's what analysts are currently thinking each central bank will do: US Federal Reserve: 99% chance of hold Bank of England: 71% chance of 0.25 percentage point hike Bank of Japan: expected to remain unchanged Speaking ahead of the Fed's meeting (Federal Open Market Committee, or FOMC), head of research at Pepperstone, Chris Weston, said it shouldn't result in too many surprises. "In theory, the FOMC meeting should be a low-volatility affair, but it is a risk that needs to be managed," he said. "We should see the median projection for the 2023 fed funds rate remaining at 5.6%, offering the bank the flexibility to hike again in November, should the data warrant it." Of course, these aren't set in stone — we'll have to wait until each central bank's respective meeting to know for sure.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What will foreign central banks decide at their interest rates meetings?

Here's what analysts are currently thinking each central bank will do:
Speaking ahead of the Fed's meeting (Federal Open Market Committee, or FOMC), head of research at Pepperstone, Chris Weston, said it shouldn't result in too many surprises.
"In theory, the FOMC meeting should be a low-volatility affair, but it is a risk that needs to be managed," he said.
"We should see the median projection for the 2023 fed funds rate remaining at 5.6%, offering the bank the flexibility to hike again in November, should the data warrant it."
Of course, these aren't set in stone — we'll have to wait until each central bank's respective meeting to know for sure.

image.altText: For Rent sign

props.synopsis: The one-bedroom apartment was advertised as a delightful ground-floor apartment with its own private courtyard. Within a day the price was raised twice due to increased market interest.

title.children: It was advertised as a delightful ground-floor apartment. Within a day, the rental price had gone up twice

image.altText: Wallabies players applaud Fijian players in a guard of honour after their Rugby World Cup match.

props.synopsis: The Wallabies' loss to Fiji for the first time in 69 years has left their Rugby World Cup hopes on a precipice, with penalties and ill discipline costing them dearly. But it could have been worse. Here are five quick hits from Fiji's momentous victory.

title.children: Five quick hits — Penalties, squad questions and a 'massively important' bonus point as Wallabies lose to Fiji

image.altText: A firefighter dousing a massive blaze in water, smoke, trees burning.

props.synopsis: Longer and complex fire seasons are placing increased pressure on rural fire brigades but a shortage of volunteers has raised concerns only a handful will be shouldering the load.

title.children: Fears lives could be lost due to lack of volunteer rural firefighters during 'traumatic fire season'

image.altText: The Voice to Parliament referendum booklet opened to the pages outlining how the Yes and No arguments will appear

props.synopsis: Unlike federal elections, a majority of Australian states will need to support the Voice to Parliament in order for the change to pass.

title.children: A double majority is needed for the Voice referendum to pass. What does that mean and how does it work?

image.altText: Two quinoa salad bowls with sweet potato, baby spinach, tinned tuna, pine nuts and red onion to illustrate our simple recipe.

props.synopsis: The average Australian diet barely scraped a pass on the healthy diet score card, with most adults eating too few veg and too much junk.

title.children: The CSIRO says we're eating too much junk and not enough veggies — here's how to improve your diet

image.altText: build-to-rent tenant Carly Hulls

props.synopsis: Build-to-rent developments are new to Australia but with long leases and freedom to have pets and make alterations they are being tipped as an answer to the rental crisis. But affordability remains a problem, writes Angelique Lu

title.children: Carly needed a stable rental home to raise her baby. A build-to-rent scheme was the answer

image.altText: A solemn Aboriginal woman stands next to a river amid dense vegetation. She wears red top, black cardie.

props.synopsis: Descendants of Aboriginal people who survived the Pinjarra massacre are undecided on how they will vote in the Voice to Parliament referendum.

title.children: Cheryl's people were massacred in this place. She hopes the Voice will further truth-telling and healing

image.altText: Various private health fund cards

props.synopsis: The government spends billions of dollars a year subsidising private health insurance, particularly for those over 65. Could the money be better-used by investing directly in hospitals and primary care?

title.children: Who really benefits from private health insurance rebates? Not people who need cover the most

image.altText: A long-haired man in a black wetsuit stands on the sand, holding a long yellow surfboard with a snake on the front of it.

props.synopsis: Authorities say the man had a permit to keep native animals, but did not have a permit to take the reptile out in public.

title.children: Pet python surfing session costs owner thousands after wildlife officers chase up viral footage

image.altText: A fighter jet flies throguh the air

props.synopsis: US military officials are appealing for the public's help to find an F-35 aircraft, which a pilot ejected from over South Carolina.

title.children: US military hunting for missing fighter jet after pilot ejects

image.altText: A profile picture of UK comedian Russell Brand

props.synopsis: Britain's BBC says it is "urgently looking into the issues" raised by allegations of sexual assault made against the broadcaster's former employee, British comedian and actor Russell Brand, who denies the accusations.

title.children: BBC investigating after sexual assault allegations made against Russell Brand

image.altText: propeller airplane with REX logo sits on tarmac at dusk.

props.synopsis: Local governments own and operate hundreds of airports around the country, but many operate at a loss and rely on ratepayers to stay in the air. Councils say more funding is needed to support their community's "valuable asset".

title.children: 'Too crucial to fail': Why your local council is likely funding an airport that isn't profitable

image.altText: Woman holding open an empty pink wallet

props.synopsis: Family courts have never formerly acknowledged the financial impacts of abuse when dividing assets. But there are growing calls to better consider the devastating reality.

title.children: Calls to reform laws to stop DV survivors walking out with 'absolutely nothing'

image.altText: Ukraine

props.synopsis: Ukraine says it has recaptured Klishchiivka, an eastern village on the southern flank of Bakhmut, which fell into Russian hands during months of heavy fighting,

title.children: Zelenskyy praises soldiers for recapturing village near Bakhmut

image.altText: A woman's silhouette.

props.synopsis: Legal experts say a program that offers intermediaries to support people with a cognitive impairment, including mental illness or intellectual disability, during police interviews and court hearings is too limited and excludes many who would benefit from it.

title.children: After Claire experienced domestic violence, going to court was 'terrifying'. She says people like her need more support

image.altText: Rescuer in red hard hat stands before a mountain of crumpled  buildings

props.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happened.

title.children: Libyan flood survivors face new water contamination risk, Gold Coast man fined for surfing with pet snake. Catch up with The Loop

image.altText: Drew Barrymore with an upset expression recording a video.

props.synopsis: Drew Barrymore's initial decision to return to the air on Monday without her three union writers and with picketers outside her studio was met with criticism.

title.children: Drew Barrymore postpones return of daytime talk show until after Hollywood strikes

image.altText: A small parchment book with Arabic script

props.synopsis: Khaled Sabsabi was looking for exceptional stories in Muslim families' homes when he found a manuscript collection bigger than any owned by museums.

title.children: 'Mind-blowing' collections uncovered as artist looks to the suburbs for untold stories

image.altText: Man holds knife to staff behind counter of fast food restaurant.

props.synopsis: Crime-affected businesses in Queensland's north consider no longer accepting cash in a bid to protect their workers. But some worry the financial impacts could be crippling.

title.children: Small businesses weigh up the costs of going cashless after armed robberies, theft

image.altText: A composite photo of Wang Yi and Jake Sullivan.

props.synopsis: White House national security adviser Jake Sullivan meets with Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi in Malta for 12 hours over two days, as the world's two largest economies seek to stabilise troubled relations.

title.children: US and Chinese representatives meet for 12 hours in Malta

image.altText: A girl wearing a navy blue school uniform in front of a brick school building.

props.synopsis: What teenagers in regional Victoria are thinking about the Voice and what it means for the future.

title.children: 'I'm excited to show my support': Young Victorians share their thoughts on the Voice to Parliament
